content: "lie" is not a valid tag, so I have removed it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle

Very nice problem and clear statement. Only critique is that you need to specify that you need the output in ascending order (or accept arbitrary order outputs).

For fun, I was thinking about the case with large N. We can do Gaussian elimination with bitsets to find a basis for the set of solutions in O(N^3/32) with any number of liars, but I think it's exponential time to pinpoint a solution with the given number of liars.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Constraints allow for a simple solution

Nice puzzle! The explanation helps. 

In its current shape I think it's a pretty good fit for medium, but the max size of 10 seems a little easy. If you are careful to only guess the combinations with valid number of liars instead of all possible permutations, you can have 42 people with five liars, and that's less than a million guesses.

I was trying to figure out if there was a way to write a logic solver that could make deductions like "if 1 is a liar iff 2 is a liar" or "2 is a liar, so remove all 2 from statements, updating T/L if needed". Eventually though, I couldn't find a way to search through enough statements without including a catch-all statement with all the people, and then the solver walked through a sizeable fractions of all 2^N possibilities. Maybe I was missing something, but letting N go up to a thousand could make an interesting Hard puzzle.

I like the puzzle too but i think you need to add a little description of the example's solution. Like "If 0 is telling the truth then 1 is a liar because 0 > 1 = L. But this implies that 2 is also a liar because 1 > 2 = T is a lie. We have two liar so 0 cannot have told the truth in the first time so 0 is the liar." I don't think my text is perfect, but i think it's a good idea to had something like this to help understand the puzzle. I don't know if this is a big hint for the resolution, it may be the downside of my proposition.

Nice. Perhaps a source of confusion could be the extent of the statement "If someone is lying, then he inverses everything he says (truth became lie and lie became truth)."
Perhaps another example could be useful to clarify?
So if 1 and 2 tell the truth and 3 is a liar then possibly:
1>2>3=L is a true statement, 3 is a liar
1>3>2=L - 3 lied about 2
1>3>2>3=T ? 3 lied about 2 saying 3 was a liar ?
3>1>2>3>1=T ?? 3 lied about 1, then lied about what 1 said.
*also* typo begining -> beginning, messing truth -> messy truth, width begining -> short sentences more liars

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's very original puzzle
Nice puzzle.
Interestingly invented. I liked the idea.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
nice
nice
Ambiguous output format.
im cluelessk
Each Testcase must be different to its corresponding validator to avoid hardcoding.

I edited to improve the formatting and fix several typos (mostly those that were making the statement painful to read/understand).

There isn't always a solution. And if there is, it is not necessarily unique:
2
1
0>1=L
1>0=L
The statement should mention something about that (e.g. there always exists a unique solution to the given testcases).
Please correct the constraints.

Hello and thanks for your comment ^^
Whitch constraints are you talking about ? 
And in what form can I correct them ?

Thanks for your comment ^v^

Thanks for correcting me on my typos. It help a lot for my first contributions.

Yes, a case can have multiple outcome. I'll make more clear that for every test only one solution is possible. Thanks a lot :P

Thanks for your comment it help a lot ^^

On the 3 first test cases it is the case that the validator is the same as the Test Case, but For the 2 final validator, it is not the case, to avoid hardcoding.

I've done this so there is not "bad surprise" but if you think this is a security issue, I can fix it.
Ahah no worries. Keep calm, think, and you'll be able to find a nice solution I'm sure ^^

More ambiguousness: you translate NUM>NUM>NUM to english without saying which NUM matches which. Use ABC.

The meaning of being a liar is kind of vague too, you probably ought to give a specific example of what constitutes lies. In the real world, it's a lie to say "X told me that Y" when X didn't say anything, yet that appears out of scope to your problem. But hard to tell for sure.
Thanks !
Thanks !

Thanks you !
I'll probably make another one with differents types of people and more choice !
Thanks !

Thank you. I got so much nice comments from this. As my first contribution it is a bless. 
I am gonna look forward at making more !

I see.
Thank you for the typos, I corrected them ^^

Also, it is true that this puzzle is a bit confusing. I am going to explain the exemple I gave and maybe re-formulate the sentence or add more information. 

Thank you !

Great idea !
I'm adding this right now, thanks you a lot.

This is not that much of a big hint : It doesn't gave any logical operator you can deduce from, for exemple A>B=T for the state of A and B. Maybe this solution is a hint if you want to search for all possibilities, but in the futures challenges of the same type it will not be possible.

Great point.

For now, this puzzle is a medium, and I don't really exept the player to make a logic tree of it.
I'll make a version 2, which will be hard, and use more state that juste truth / lie, and way more persons.

Thanks for your review :P

Thank you !

As I say for CarlWalsh in the comment, I'll make a "hard" version with more states and way more persons.

Oh and yeah I thought I already said that you need the output in ascending order, but I didn't !

My mistake, I'll correct it.
Thank you !

Yes, my bad !

Thank you !

> Where NUM is a person number. You can have 1 to a hundred.

Yet that doesn't happen.

> Ambiguous output format.
I don't get what you mean here. You just answer by responding with all the liars, each separated by spaces. And there is an exemple if you don't understand. What have you not understand, so I can help you ?

> you translate NUM>NUM>NUM to english without saying which NUM matches which. Use ABC.
I corrected that part a bit, even so I don't really understand what you mean. I didn't use ABC because each NUM is different and it's easier to explain what is as an input like this. If you have some trouble, I've posted a Regex of the input so it really shouldn't be a problem.

> The meaning of being a liar is kind of vague too
No it isn't. I said:
`If someone is lying, then he inverses everything he says (truth became lie and lie became truth).`

> Yet that doesn't happen.
And ? Is that a problem with the puzzle itself ?
Plus, I've specified "you CAN", which doesn't mean it actually occure.

You seam very upset for absolutly no reason, but if you have some trouble, please tell me !

>> Ambiguous output format.
>I don't get what you mean here.
You ask for output of a set of numbers in a serialized format without specifying the order.  Someone could answer "2 1" to test "A width beginning", which would be correct according to the statement but rejected by the platform.

>I didn't use ABC because each NUM is different
That's my point. Each NUM is different, so use different variable names. Right now, we have to assume and guess that they match by ordering, when it could be perffectly explicitly clear at no  cost.

Your correction makes a "creative" use of the word recursive.

>> The meaning of being a liar is kind of vague too
> No it isn't.
You don't get to decide that :)
I actually gave you a specific example.
It's off-topic to the statement, but the kicker is it's impossible to tell at that point in the statement.

>> Yet that doesn't happen.
>And ? Is that a problem with the puzzle itself ?
>Plus, I've specified "you CAN", which doesn't mean it actually occure.
It doesn't make the statement *wrong*. It makes the statement *bad*.
Constraints are there for a reason: they determine what class of algorithm can be used. Lying about it is morally wrong.
Then again, that part was before I got to fully understand the NUM/NUM ambiguity above, so it may not be as off as I thought. I'll measure when I'm in the mood to solve.

>You seam very upset
I'm not quite sure what makes you think that.

>if you have some trouble, please tell me !
That's literally what the comment was about.

All in all, your statement as a whole suffers from the "hindsight" problem: all (well, most) of the information needed to solve is there, and it's trivial to verify *after* it's been solved. But it does a bad job at getting the reader to reach that ah-ha point because of all the ambiguity hurdles in the middle.

IMHO, you ought to write up a complete explanation of the example's resolution.
BTW, the very first test case is the one blessed by the platform as "the example". Use that one for clarifications unless there's a good reason not to.

> You ask for output of a set of numbers in a serialized format without specifying the order.
Ohh my bad you are absolutly right. I thought I said somewhere that the output is in ascending order but I didn't ! I'll correct this.

> It doesn't make the statement *wrong*. It makes the statement *bad*.
I get what you mean. As you recommended, I've made the exemple solution detailled, so it is easier to understand.

>  Each NUM is different, so use different variable names.
The thing is, it could be different, but in some case it isn't, and since there are a arbitrairy amout of "NUM" I can't really make a easy to understand sattement to explan this.
Once again, there is the regex of the sentence below if you need really clean detailled.

Try it, read the exemple solution, maybe it will become clearer.

>The thing is, it could be different, but in some case it isn't
That's the good thing with variables. They're allowed to be equal as well as different.
The regex, in addition to being of no help whatsoever on the semantics side, is completely redundant.

Explaining the example is a good step forward. But since all clauses are rank-1, it doesn't really help understand the semantics you intend to put in what it means to lie when asserting a rank-N fact.

The examples section you give don't refer to the same example, that's pretty confusing too.

I think if you can't solve all testcases with hardcoding, it's okay, because you won't get any XP without 100%.
I like it better, if all Testcases and Validators are different, In the end it's your contribution and your decision.

Also, this challenge is not supposed to be hard, only "medium".
Yeah, maybe I should, but in the Find the liars 2 It will. This is my first contribution, and I need to learn more !

You write that 2 <= n <= 9m but that's not true for "a messing truth", it should be 2 <= n <= 10

2 <= l <= 9 is not true for the first Testcase, it should be 1 <= l <= 9

You are absoletly right, my bad !

I've corrected it.
